natural problem:
The students at Sherry Curtis School were able to vote for one or more events for their field day. Below are the top three choices. List the names of the choices from most popular to least popular, separated by commas.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|} \hline
Event & Kickball & Picnic & Softball \\ \hline 
& & &\\[-1.5ex]
Fraction liking event & $\frac{11}{30}$ & $\frac{7}{20}$ & $\frac{5}{12}$ \\[1ex] \hline
\end{tabular}
natural solution: Rewriting the fractions to have a common denominator of $60,$ we have \begin{align} \text{Kickball: }&\frac{22}{60} \\ \text{Picnic: }&\frac{21}{60} \\ \text{Softball: }&\frac{25}{60} \end{align} So the order is $\boxed{\text{Softball, Kickball, Picnic}}.$

The problem you've provided is more about data analysis and ordering, which doesn't involve the kind of logical or mathematical theorems that Isabelle is designed to handle. This problem could be solved with a simple programming language or even just a spreadsheet.

a_2.formal problem:
This problem is related to data analysis and comparison of fractions which doesn't have a direct translation to Isabelle's formal language as it's primarily used for theorem proving and not for data analysis tasks. However, you can define the fractions and make comparisons using Isabelle's real numbers and inequality functionality. 

Here's a rough approximation:

```
definition Kickball_votes :: real where "Kickball_votes = 11 / 30"
definition Picnic_votes :: real where "Picnic_votes = 7 / 20"
definition Softball_votes :: real where "Softball_votes = 5 / 12"

lemma:
shows  "Softball_votes > Kickball_votes"
and "Kickball_votes > Picnic_votes"
```

This set of definitions and lemma would prove that Softball was the most popular choice, followed by Kickball, and then Picnic. But please note that this is a very unusual use of Isabelle.

a_2.informal problem: There were three options for an outdoor activity: kickball, picnic, and softball. The votes for each activity were represented as fractions of the total votes. Kickball received 11 out of 30 votes, picnic received 7 out of 20 votes, and softball received 5 out of 12 votes. Which activity was the most popular, which was the second most popular, and which was the least popular? According to the results, softball was the most popular, followed by kickball, and then picnic.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Kickball Picnic Softball :: real
assumes h0 : "Kickball = 11 / 30"
and h1 : "Picnic = 7 / 20"
and h2 : "Softball = 5 / 12"
shows  "Softball > Kickball \<and> Kickball > Picnic"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The students at Sherry Curtis School were able to vote for one or more events for their field day. Below are the top three choices. List the names of the choices from most popular to least popular, separated by commas.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|} \hline
Event & Kickball & Picnic & Softball \\ \hline 
& & &\\[-1.5ex]
Fraction liking event & $\frac{11}{30}$ & $\frac{7}{20}$ & $\frac{5}{12}$ \\[1ex] \hline
\end{tabular} The final Answer is \text{Softball, Kickball, Picnic}
 ### Proof
 Rewriting the fractions to have a common denominator of $60,$ we have \begin{align} \text{Kickball: }&\frac{22}{60} \\ \text{Picnic: }&\frac{21}{60} \\ \text{Softball: }&\frac{25}{60} \end{align} So the order is $\boxed{\text{Softball, Kickball, Picnic}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes Kickball Picnic Softball :: real
assumes h0 : "Kickball = 11 / 30"
and h1 : "Picnic = 7 / 20"
and h2 : "Softball = 5 / 12"
shows  "Softball > Kickball \<and> Kickball > Picnic"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given that the proportions of time spent on kickball, picnic and softball are 11/30, 7/20 and 5/12 respectively, is it true that more time is spent on softball than kickball, and more time is spent on kickball than on the picnic?
